the first thing is just what I said before um right unit test and that sounds weird to say right unit test for
your you know research code but if you're model is not doing what you think
it's doing I mean that's bad science out of the gate right like if your model is like accidentally ignoring one of its
inputs then it's not going to be doing the right thing so if you write tests and the way we tend to do it is take a
data set like the one you want to use get a very small version you know maybe it has two or three instances in it and
now write a unit test that takes that data reads it in puts it through your model checks that you know checks that
the output looks right that the model can run on it without cck crashing checks that the model can learn to predict it perfectly because if you have
three instances your model should be able to learn it perfectly things like that um and you make these actual unit tests that that run along with your code
then that gives you this really simple but basic guarantee the code is doing at
least sort of what you think it's doing so that's one I would say really important aspect another one is that
typically you're going to run a lot of experiments you know maybe with minor variations I'll vary some hyper
parameters or I'll try different kinds of word embeddings or or I'll try different number of hidden units and so
what you want to do is you want to structure your code that makes it as easy as possible to run these experiments and so what that speaks to
then is making a real clean division between what I'll call library code and
experiment code so I want one code that's like this is the details of how my model works and this is the details
of how data gets read off disk and I want this code in a module that's like well tested and it's not going to change
and now I want to run an exp experiment and maybe that experiment needs to point into a specific data path and it needs

very heavily on that module and just you know all it's really doing is taking the
parameters that I fed in and calling that model and so when you separate
things out this way it makes it really easy to you know run an experiment you don't have to be saying oh gosh when I
